description:
I was a little nervous coming to this place after the 3 stars but i decided to give it a try just in case it's a hidden gem. The staff were friendly greeted me as soon as I entered. I was craving won ton soup so I ordered the combo which included beef pork chicken shrimp and scallops. A pretty good size bowl of soup filled with food and not just broth for 10$. The soup was hot in temperature freshly made . I got a little greedy and ordered the lunch combo orange chicken over rice for 8.50$ it came with a full plate of orange chicken Crispy and a bowl of white rice. The orange chicken sauce was a little tangy but over all good. 

I'm good with this spot I'll come back
author: Mike H.

description:
I thought it was really hard to find Hakka food in SF and finally i found it here!!!! Many Hakka dishes here reminded me back to my hometown and family and also my childhood.

Good atmosphere and hospitality. The price is reasonable and all dishes come with a large portion. Cant wait to go back there!
author: Tiratiwan L.

description:
I came here for the first time with my parents and I really enjoyed the food. Their steamed fish and fish soup were really good. The best part was that it was reasonably priced. The steamed fish was very fresh, and the meat was cooked to perfection and not overcooked where it became dry. Additionally, we also ordered the steamed giant clams. When I have ordered this at other restaurants, the vermicelli noodles are sometimes very plain. The way that this restaurant prepared it was great because they had a lot of garlic and the right amount of the soy sauce mix that made the noodles perfect! The clam itself was also very tender. Another plus is that it was very affordable. We also ordered a snow pea leaves dish. Not the best that i have had, but it was not overly oily and I could tell that the vegetables were fresh as well. I will be coming back to this restaurant again soon. 

Great price and great food! I also appreciated that the waiters are not pushy and try to get you to order a lot of dishes. They gave good recommendations and were able to give us the details of the different dishes when we were trying to decide what we wanted to order. 

Parking can be a little tough, depending on what time you arrive, so I would recommend trying to find parking a block or two away and don't forget to give yourself extra time to find parking.
author: Lynn T.

description: Our friends invited us for a holiday banquet at this restaurant, and we were surprised at the quality of their dishes. This was especially true of their sticky rice chicken and Peking Duck!  It was one of the best Chinese banquet that we ever had in SF!
author: Stephen Y.

description:
Homestyle Cantonese cooking. I wasn't impressed with the snow cabbage noodle soup.

The crispy chicken and filet fish with bok choy was alright.

The servers were friendly.  As for the kitchen, don't look inside as you are passing by the bathroom.
author: Jboogie L.

description: Good old fashion home STYLE cooking. Good food and Service. Food is like mom's cooking and fresh the price is cheap and a great value for the food you get.
author: Andrew M.

description: Try and find a Chinese restaurant that can beat this restaurants rice. Everything is authentic here never have we had a problem ordering anything. Love this place.
author: Brad Z.

description: This restaurant has mixed reviews but we have always had great food here. We have had takeout and family dinners. Highly recommend the Peking duck and stuffed chicken...both more reasonable than many other places. The Hakka flavored meats and tofu are very tasty. Had the best steamed bass on a family dinner! The waitresses have been very friendly too...even though very busy sometimes.
author: Gale H.

description:
It's my go-to place for comfort food & family banquet! Every dish is always consistently good! Staff really friendly, willing to accommodate your allergy avoidance & modify the dish.

If you BYO fish, the fee is 4+ times cheaper than other restaurants.

Must try:
- Pumpkin fries w/ crab (live) or shrimp
- Steamed cat fish (live) & soup
- Steamed giant clams
- Wine sauce beef
- Lobster (live) noodles
- Steam clams in egg
- Chicken stuffed with sticky rice (pre-order)
- Steamed streaky pork (Chinese bacon) w/ shrimp sauce
author: Bkwm J.

description:
My new favorite chinese restaurant in San Francisco.   I brought my parents and they loved all the food, especially the Hakka dishes.   We especially loved the Hakka style fried tofu and the ginger green onion beef!

A very family friendly environment.  My kids loved the food there also!
author: Super T.

description: We order a steamed fish, half chicken and some veggies. Very delicious and the service is great. Authentic Hakka food. Love it!
author: Stefanie Y.

description: Pretty poor customer service. I called to ask if the vegetarian food has fish sauce and they tell me to call back. I call back and the machine picks up and of course, you can't leave a message. Then, I get a hold of someone, and ask if the vegetarian food has fish sauce. She interrupts me and says she doesn't know. The restaurant making the food can't tell me what is in it?
author: Vani A.

description: Great place to have dinner with friends or family. Never eat here alone please. Most of the foods are good. I like the roast pork, roast chicken, etc.
author: David S.

description:
We've ordered food here at least 6 times in the past. We finally stopped going there because there were not enough dishes that we could order and feel satisfied enough after each ordered meal. 

Pros:
Sweet and sour pork - I'd say that among all the neighborhood Chinese restaurants, they knew how to make the pork well. The meat was soft and not hardened that you would get when it had been deep friend multiple times. The batter was crispy enough. The sauce was not overly sweet.

Cons:
Chinese broccoli - If you could overcook Chinese broccoli, it says a lot about the quality of the food. The broccoli was soggy. Very disappointing.

Chinese bacon with mustard green - This dish is a pork belly dish. I ordered this dish a number of times. The meat was freezer-burned each time.

I liked the owner. She was always very friendly to me, on the phone and in person. I just wished that she would taste the food and ask herself if she could tolerate soggy Chinese broccoli or freezer-burned meat.
author: GR Z.

description:
Came here for my dad's birthday and I have to say, we were definitely not disappointed! Perhaps we came at a slow time, because we were the only ones there beside one other family. We weren't  complaining, though, because this means we would get our food fast! 
Since we were the only ones ordering at the time, so the service was super speedy. I personally like the atmosphere of this restaurant: chill, and family oriented. 
The food was excellent. We came here specifically for their Peking duck, and oh boy, was it great. The skin remained crispy even after an hour, the seasoning was just right, even the buns were delicious. We ordered some other items, too, such as steamed catfish with black beans, Peking spareribs, scallop fried rice, chicken chowmein. The food took a reasonable amount of time to arrive; no complaints here. The waitress suggested this sweet soup that was made up of sweet taro and tapioca; it was a nice touch at the end of the meal.
The price is reasonable, too, much less than we he had expected. Will definitely come back!
author: Karetta L.

description: This is a nice neighborhood restaurant my girlfriend and I frequent. The food is great, authentic, and affordable. My favorite is the Clay Pot with Fish. The service is also very nice, extra friendly if you speak Chinese :)
author: Shane W.

description:
Two years later, we returned and had a nice meal at this neighborhood Chinese restaurant. The waiter had trouble with his English, but everything worked out.

She had beef chow fun with gravy. I had beef stew clay pot. The beef was only about half meat and half tendon. I prefer more meat. It tasted good with the rice though. We also had steamed rice noodles with beef. 

Was satisfied with everything. Food arrived rapidly. 

Prices are still very good and portions are large.
author: Steven G.

description: Very average Chinese food.... Came in as a group of 8 and the service was good! Very nice waiter/ waitress! We were all super hungry, and finished everything regardless! The soup was not flavorful, but I did enjoyed their lettuce wrap!
author: Michelle C.

description: First time here, food was delicious..had won ton soup, bbq fried rice and sesame chicken. Great service, very nice, attentive and polite unlike other places. Will definitely be returning for more!!
author: Linda M.

description:
I forgot to take pictures.  

This is my first time going to this restaurant so I am using Yan Yan Seafood Restaurant and Empero Taste as a reference benchmark since the prices are the same. This was on a Tuesday night at 7PM with my mom. Typically when my mom and I got to any chinese restaurant for the first time, we will order two dishes to use as a reference point as listed below. Before we even went in, there was not a single customer inside and as we all know, that is a bad sign since even the caucasians knows not to go to any chinese restaurant if no chinese goes to it as that is a major No No but I just had to see if the high Yelp! ratings after multiple change of ownership within 3 years can be trusted! ;)

1) Beef Chow Dried Chow Hor Fun or stir-fried flat wide noodles $6.50 - the waitress has never heard of this dish in her entire life when the waiter told her it's just Beef instead of Chicken. This should already be a bad sign. ;)  When this dish came out - it was about 2/3rd the portion size of Yan Yan and Empero Taste. There was no much beef as basically they took very thin slice of beef and cut it into pea size pieces. The flavor was average as it used too much baking soda which had had bitter taste but lacks what the chinese calls wok hei.

2) Mandarin/Peking Spare Ribs $7.50 which are just a type of Sweet and Sour Pork Chops - When this dish came out, it was 1/2 the size of Yan Yan and Empero Taste as far as portion size goes. And as these are known as gwat or bone in chinese, they really defined it as basically picture it like this, they bought Pork Chop End Sirloin Chops, the cheapest type of pork chops available at the supermarket and then basically kept 90% of the meat to sell in other dishes and gave you all the leftover bones instead, similar to what the local family dog would get after the owners are finished with their meat that included bones on it. The flavor was decent.

Forgot to mention earlier that they provide complimentary Spanish Redskin peanuts but there is no house soup and dessert which appears to be the normal these days at Chinese restaurants. Yan Yan does not provide free house soup during dinner but they always provide free marinated chicken feet for lunch and dinner with a unlimited quantity of desserts of which you can choose from 5 different options.

Basically, for the price, it is a major rip-off in another way to say it. Yan Yan is good but Empero Taste is even more gooder with bigger portions at the same price as Yan Yan as a fellow friend pointed out which was also how I discovered Empero Taste.
author: Vincent P.

description:
Double check your bill if you ever eat here. We were overcharged for every single item we ordered (see photo). Granted, we asked for spinach to be added to the eggplant dish so we had a mixture of two vegetables instead of all eggplant. This substitution amounted to an extra $1.50? Awesome.

In the end, we were overcharged about $4 (if you include the extra charge for spinach) for a $30 meal. That's 13% of our meal. Sure, $4 isn't a lot, but if you multiply that by the 12 or so tables they may overcharge at any given time throughout the day, it could add up to a lot. Also, what about the principle of the matter?!

Fortunately, my fiancé's fortune cookie told him he is "good with finances" (see photo), which prompted him to ask the lady to recalculate the bill based on the real menu prices.

No apologies from any of the staff. I guess this was just business as usual at the Dragon River Restaurant?
author: Gail S.

description: This restaurant is very good. Tasty, fresh Chinese food for a good value. They make a great spicy tofu & broccoli dish. Also, their Szechuan spicy beef is delicious. Very friendly & fast service. We order from there all the time.
author: Judy A.

description:
We haven't been back here since they changed owners.  The restaurant was refurbished.  Gone are the specials posted on the walls.  The food was ok, nothing to call home about.  I do have to say that some dishes were too hot and spicy.  The lamb clay pot was a goopy mess.  Really, lay off on the corn starch and everyone will be happy.

I did not like the fact that all the dishes were served on fancy square plates.  Yep that means portions were small.  

I want to like you but sorry, you're not going to make the cut on our birthday rotation.
author: Wendy H.

description:
This doesn't happen very often, but I have been having the most serious craving for good Chinese steamed rice so I finally make use of my Dragon River bookmark and gave this place a try. My credible source said this place was once better a few years back before a divorce that took place, but my visit was still marked by a very celebratory atmosphere where every table was filled, including two separate and ongoing birthday banquets to further the family-oriented vibe. 

This décor reeked authenticity as special Hakka dishes were written on the walls with a modest layout that will take you back in time. My order of half Hakka chicken ($7.75) came with a sizable portion of steamed chicken and a tasty side of ginger sauce. The chicken was delicious but I didn't anticipate it to tastes identical to the Cantonese steamed chicken. My order of stir fry string beans ($5.95) from the wall specials was one of the better ones I've had. The flavor encompassed a generous portion of string beans stir fried with jalapenos, plenty of juicy gooey grounded pork, and a tiny spoon of red pepper to give a slight kick. I thought the string beans could be stirred in the wok a little longer for it to dry but the grounded pork was a major obstacle since the ones being served were ultra fatty. I thought their steamed rice was okay but for some reason it didn't hit the spot. 

There was no noticeable difference in service as I was treated the same as any other big tables. To my delight I was given a complimentary sweet red bean dessert and fortune cookie afterward to give it a strong finish. The red bean dessert had hint of mandarin orange that I thought was interesting but still delicious. I thought the meal was a strong 3.5 stars until I discovered a $1.80 overcharge for the string beans. What a let down after a pretty decent meal! It's time to go back to Eight Immortals where authentic expressions were just as affordable and on point. 3 stars for the overall experience.
author: Daniel L.

description: Great folks who own the place and it's delicious too! Fair value for the food. I come here often
author: B H.

description:
Had the chance to try some new dishes here this past weekend!
With such a "bare bones" interior, the food at Dragon River continues to be full of awesomely delicious flavors-

Crab and Mushroom Soup- 5 Stars, not overly salty, full of refined flavor, and made with fresh crab meat.

Chicken Wings-5 Stars, in a finger licking delicate sauce (see photo) and a balanced combination of sweet, sour, and spicy!

Beef Stew Won Ton-4 Stars, 5 Stars for the won ton because they really are some of the best I've tasted in the world, having lived and worked in the Far East. DR's won ton are perfectly round, plump, firm, slightly crunchy and juicy. Minus 1 Star because I found a tiny little bone in the beef stew. 

As always, for those with food additive and preservative allergies, Dragon River continues to do a respectfully "YAY" job of honoring my request for no MSG. Rock On Dragon River!!!!
author: Richard T.

description:
This place is one of the best Chinese places in the area.

You should ALWAYS order "Lobster Noodles."  Their lobster noodles is $11.99!!!!  Where else are you going to find a place this cheap for a FULL lobster and a heaping plate of tasty noodles during dinner hours?  The next cheapest place I found in the bay area is $14 at dinner, but that's hard to find.  I have no clue how they can make a profit on this dish because the cheapest lobster I've seen in the supermarket is $6.99/lb and these lobsters are greater than 1 lbs., and prepared much better than you could at home.  And you know what?  The lobster is fresh and they don't cheat you.  The lobster tank is in plain view at the back and you literally WATCH them take out the live lobster.  Within 10 minutes, you will have a big plate of an entire dissected lobster on top of creamy noodles (flat egg noodles).  I also don't know how they cook it so fast.

You should also consider their crab.  I think they charge $8/lb.  Most of their crabs are probably in the 3 lbs. range or about $24.  That's pretty damn good.  Think about it.  All you 'trendy' followers love go to R&G Lounge and PPQ to get their amazing 2.5 lbs. crab for $40.  I don't know why.  Dragon River is just as good and half the price.  You also see them take it out of the tank when you order crab.  

Other stuff to try
-Remember, this is a Hakka restaurant, so they serve Hakka dishes in addition to the regular Chinese stuff
-Salt-baked Chicken - Pretty good and juicy.  This is done exactly how it's supposed to be - plain, but tender and moist.  Use their generous dipping sauces to add flavor.  
-Clay Pots - They actually stuff this very well and it's generally cheaper (under $10) than most places.  

Dessert
-They give you a free hot dessert soup at the end, based on what they make during that day.  We've had black seasame and taro dessert soups.  Free is always great!

Service
-Service might be a little slow, but that's because it's a family restaurant and the lady server has to take care of everybody.  It's not slow because she's lazy.  She's actually working 2x faster than most servers out there.  It's just a lot of dishes to bring and clean up for the size of the restaurant.  But she always brings a smile.  Please tip her for her efforts. 

Give this place a try.  If you're waiting at Sichuan House two doors over, I recommend you come in here for a treat instead.
author: Jon K.

description: I go like this place foods is good price is average. The place is clear service r great! I have friends that like that place even my parents parents friends likes it.
author: gloria y.

description: Service was terrible, wait time was 50 minutes but it took 75 before driver picked it up. So now our food will be cold. #hangry
author: Jessy K.

description:
There's a dish here that I just can't quit. 

I've never actually seen it prepared anywhere else, but it's basically Westlake beef soup with fried wontons floating around in it. Yes, you read that correctly fried wontons. 

I can't even begin to describe the depth of flavor and texture presented by this combination but it is perfect. On the menu, it's called "Supper wonton soup" presumably it's supposed to be "Super" but who knows. Make sure when you order it though, that you do tell them that you want the soup with the fried wontons, because I've ordered it once before and gotten something completely different and inferior.
author: Clarissa S.

description:
To circumvent disappointment when entering a Chinese restaurant with unknown repute, it is wise to expect Panda Express-esque dishes and be pleasantly satisfied if that standard is exceeded.  Despite the shade of authenticity in Dragon River's fare, the apparent flavor redundancies and scant standout options leave DR teetering on brink of falling into the abyss filled with forgettable restaurants.

DR's highlights include the Sliced Chinese Doughnut Cilantro-laden Soup (not the menu name, probably) that is teeming with slightly soggy yet half crispy Chinese doughnuts capable of instantly melting upon chewing, and the Beef with Mushrooms features meat so tender that it is recommended for teething toddlers and the dentured elderly alike.

Unlikely to lead a campaign to dine at Dragon River.
author: Andrew M.

description: I know my chinese food and this is very good quality food for the price. great for groups. I came here for a family dinner and got one if the set meals. Well worth it.
author: Alice L.

description:
One of my favorite Chinese restaurants in the Richmond District still with dirt cheap prices!

Came here for dinner on Saturday, so we were the only ones on the restaurant at the time.  We were thinking at first that this place must have been hit hard by the tough economic times since for the first 30 minutes of us being there, it pretty much remined quiet.  

Slowly however, folks started to trickle in, and before we knew, the whole place was packed. I'm so glad to see this place doing well, as my family and I have been coming here for years with my paternal grandma, before she passed away a few years ago. 

Anyway, we started off dinner with Corn and Minced Chicken Soup.  The soup was definitely big enough fro 6-7 people, but we only had 4 of us, so we had much left over.  6 bucks is insanely reasonable.  Soup was so  y u m m y, had great amounts of minced chicken and corn, and egg white in every bite. 

For entree's, we ordered The Szcheuan Chicken, Steak Cube with Bok Choy, and Fried Tofu with Oysters and Pork.  

Everything came out looking so juicy and appetizing...and needless to say, it all definitely was.  The Chicken was tender, and the flavor was perfectly spicy.  It also came with slices of zuccini and garlic.  Steak Cube with Bok Choy was also very good.  There was a bit too much pepper flavor for me, but overall, tasty dish.  Finally the Fried Tofu with Oysters and Pork came in a clay pot.  Tofu was cooked and fried perfectly.  I hate when the tofu breaks into pieces when  you try to pick it up, but here, it was hard on the outside, and fluffy on the inside.

Service here was typical of a Chinese restaurant.  No real thoughts here.  After our meal they gave us complimentery Tapioca and Taro dessert.  My absolute favorite hot dessert at Chinese restaurants.  I was so wanting more, so I asked the waiter, who as a very nice man, if I could have some to-go.  To my surprise he agree'd and gave a portion enough to feed 4 people for free.  =D

Every dish was under 8 bucks, so total bill came out to about $40.00.  For reasonable portions, and good pricing, Dragon River continues to be one of my favorite Chinese restaurants.
author: Cass J.

description: It took us a while after we moved into the neighborhood to find Dragon River, but I'm so glad we found them at last. What we do is order ahead and pick up our yummy dinner. The food is good. It's not the most gourmet food in town, no, but it's consistently tasty and fresh. We've settled on a standard order of a few favorites, but we've never had anything bad. I've only eaten in the restaurant once, and it was a fun family dinner. The place is family run, and it shows in the friendly service and neighborly attitude. We had a lot of bad food in our search to find our neighborhood Chinese restaurant, but our search is over. Dragon River is reasonably priced, has good food, and is run by friendly people. What more could you need?
author: Lisa A.

description: I order takeout every night; however, I just realized that I was overcharged by $10 according to the takeout menu. I asked them whether the takeout menu's prices were updated, but they told me that all prices were current; however, as the conversation proceeded, they told me that the price of every dish has actually been increased by $2 to $3. Especially, all vegetable dishes are market price, as told by the cashier.
author: Albert C.

description:
I came here with a small group of volunteers after working on a nearby project recently.  Dragon River was recommended by several of the neighbors from the Park Presidio Neighbors organization whom we assisted.

We walked into an empty restaurant on a Saturday afternoon.  Greeted by the waitress we were seated at a big round table in the corner of the restaurant.  There were several fish tanks beside our table with live crabs and what looked like catfish.  We took turns visiting the rest rooms to wash the dirt and soil from our hands.  The men's room was surprisingly clean, but we were probably the first customers of the day.

We decided to eat family style instead of having each person order for themselves.  Together we ordered two appetizers being fried won tons and potstickers, and four main dishes along with steamed rice.

The service was very good.  Our waitress was very attentive, and brought us all forks in addition to our chopsticks anticipating that some of us might not know how to use the chopsticks.  I was very much thankful to one of the volunteers who stepped up to take care of the ordering process because he spoke Mandarin fluently.  As the only Chinese person in the group I was nervous about using my "toi san" with the waitress.

Our fried won tons were pretty much what I expected.  The deep fried crispy won ton skins with a smidgen of pork filling were accompanied by a sweet and sour sauce, a red pepper sauce and a green pepper and garlic sauce.  The potstickers were big and plump with a juicy filling of pork and cabbage.  These came with a dispenser of white vinegar.  Both were okay.

The first of our main dishes was the Mu Shu Pork which came with six thin pancakes and hoisin sauce.  I was pretty wiped out from our project and didn't even focus on what I was eating.  I recall there were tender strips of pork mixed with shredded cabbage and strips of mushroom.  It's a dish I would probably never order for myself, but it tasted pretty good.  The clay pot dish with braised chicken, Chinese sausage and mushrooms was excellent.  There weren't enough pieces of the sausage to go around, but the dish was seasoned very well, and nobody really seemed to mind that the chicken pieces all had bones attached.

Do not ever order the Curry Chicken with Green Peppers and Onions.  I simply did not understand this dish.  Am I correct in saying that chicken is a tender meat?  Has anyone ever bitten into a thinly sliced piece of chicken only to encounter a super chewy piece of meat?  With that in mind I was quite baffled as to why they add baking soda to their chicken slices.  Many restaurants use baking soda to tenderize meats.  Why in hell would you need to tenderize chicken?  It just made the chicken really slimy like.  The bright yellow curry sauce had very little curry taste.  This was a truly disappointing dish.

One of the volunteers insisted on ordering a baked crab, and we left him with the entire crab and the $30 price tag that came along with it.  I'd be willing to come back and try some of their more traditional dishes as the clay pot dish was very appealing, but for what we ordered I'd give this restaurant a very average score.
author: Wilhelm Y.

description: I called in for a take out order of Beef Chow Fun Dry. When I got there, I was told they ran out of the fat noodles. Hummm, Saturday night around 8:30pm and ran out of the fat noodles? Drove over there for nothing. Rather disappointed.
author: Rod W.

description:
Definitely a great place to go have Chinese food. The place has improved on their cooking and service. 

The service is now excellent than it was before. Waiters and waitresses make sure you order the right dish. Dishes i always get and recommend are the chicken- corn soup, salty fish fried rice (my favorite), and salt baked chicken. There are more dishes i recommend but it's too much to list here. What i don't like is that when you order a dish like mongolian beef, sometimes it would be too spicy and sometimes it is not. Imagine having a dish when it's sometimes salty and sometimes it's TOO salty. 

If you're lucky by the time the check comes, ask if they have tapioca pudding. One of my favorite desserts. 

Although this is a family style restaurant, it would be better if they didn't have the TV on the wall.
author: Henry D.

description:
I been coming here for years and do notice when it goes under new management but the service has always been excellent and the food is always great in my opinion.  I always order the chicken chow mein with green vegetables, I've eaten in many chinese resturants in SF and still feel this place is the best when it comes to that plate.  
The beef plates sometimes are a bit tender but it still holds the flavor.  This place holds it down for my neighborhood.
author: Eric G.

description:
I am giving 5 stars for exceptional value 
We have found the food v good on several visits.  Actually never disappointed, though you might find different I suppose. 

Large servings, good food

Forgettable decor 
Ok service

We mostly order salt And pepper squid 
A simple dish well prepared. Be sure to get the green sauce with it

Enjoyed the hot and sour soup. Needed to add some spice for our taste but rich broth and lots of good ingredients. 

Also enjoyed  the beef with gravy
Cho fun. Again a large serving

Ordered a 2nd hot and sour soup to go. 
Total price just over 30 for two very full people.
author: Ardy H.

description: Great food, even better prices. Even if something isn't on menu, explain it,  they will make it for you. Very friendly staff and wait time is very short. If in the area I recommend very highly.
author: Richard C.

description:
My boyfriend and I had the Hot & Sour Soup and Peking Pork Spareribs. 

The Hot & Sour Soup was good. It had lots of ingredients that I wasn't familiar with, but it was good. The Hot & Sour Soup that I'm used to has bamboo shoot, black mushroom, tofu, and egg. The one at Dragon River also had shrimp, pork, and daylily buds. I also really like how they weren't skimpy on the ingredients AND the soup didn't have a layer of sesame oil. 

The Peking Pork Spareribs was good, too. The portion seemed smaller compared to most Chinese restaurant I've been to, but I guess it was justifiable for its price. The pork didn't have a whole lot of bones, which I think makes it even more worth it. 

Two tables down, those people ordered the Walnut Shrimp and Chicken with Green Onions and Oil which looked and smelled very delicious. I would like to try those next time. 

They have a vast selection! My boyfriend was a little disappointed that they didn't have General Tso's Chicken. :( 

The place was kind of dirty. The soy sauce bottle was sticky on the outside and had gunk on the inside. There was a HUGE fly flying around. The service was not bad. They were prompt to take away your dishes after you're finished, which I thought was nice to not have dirty dishes sitting around and watch the sauce or itty-bitty bits solidify. The waiter was nice. He gave us forks after we ordered; he probably assumed we didn't know how to use chopsticks. No offense taken. :) I like my forks!

3.5 stars. ;)
author: Jennifer L.

description: Driving around the area in the mood for some Chinese food. Yelped really quick to make a selective choice. Saw this with some good reviews decided to stop by. Walked in staff was really nice sat down and opened up the menu and ordered. Lots of great choices. Honey walnut prawns lemon chicken and beef chow mien.  Yummy food was really quick. Will definitely come here again. Thanks yelp.
author: C. S.

description: Under a new owner again and this time, I am impressed.  The owners are a mom and dad who has a little boy who hang out at the the restaurant.  The food is great and the service is wonderful.  I am so glad they changed owership to someone who is competent and is passionate about food and their quality.  The price is reasonable and the service is great.  Place is packed on the weekends.  No complaints at all.  Chicken corn soup is the best!
author: Wayne W.

description: Came in here for dinner on a Wednesday night and the waiter was extremely friendly to us. This is a family run business and everybody is extremely friendly here. The food tasted good. The best part is you could design your own dish and they will make it for you. I hardly rave about any Chinese restaurant in the city, but this is a must go restaurant for authentic Chinese food.
author: Bob C.

description:
No complaints from my end. Came here with a few friends last night who've been frequenting Dragon River for the last 10 years, so they were familiar with the previous owner/management. I took their word for it in that the quality of food hasn't suffered as a result of the change.

The seafood hotpot was good. The mongolian beef was savory and not too salty. The chicken won-ton soup wasn't too diluted. The random scrambled eggs with sauteed beef that my friend ordered was surprisingly pleasant, too. Feeding four grown men adequately for $34 is a win in my book.
author: Joe A.

description:
This has been my family's to go to family restaurant for the past 15 years. I love it here. Hakka food at its best outside of Hakka?

Fatty pork with preserved vegetables. Even though it is pork belly meat, the greasiness if fried and braised out of the meat. Strange concept I still can't wrap my mind around... but I get its like rendering the fat.

Red wine beef tripe with sour vegetables. My favorite! The red wine is bitter and goes well with the sourness of the vegetables. A little vinegar makes this dish very aromatic. Definitely a Yummy in my Tummy dish!

Salt baked chicken. You would think the chicken would be very salty and dried out because it's covered in salt and baked, BUT this has got to be the most moist and delicious chicken I've ever had

Other things to try are their shrimp paste squid and fried shrimp balls.

Don't forget to save room for dessert. Their sweet soup changes eat day but they normally have taro coconut milk tapioca soup on fridays! My faaaaaaaavorite!

I love this place! This is soul food to any Hakka Chinese in the area.
author: Derrick H.

description:
this place has really good food!!! 
pop stickers are amazing, I've never had some that I had really liked so I was skeptical about these yet they surpassed my expectations. The chicken chow mein is delicious, the steam rice is ok, their beef with oyster sauce is bomb!! overall a good 5 star restaurant and it's just across the street from my boyfriends place so we always order for take out.
author: Mia S.

description:
Meh. Under the new management doesn't mean better. In fact quite opposite. Chicken noodles were dripping grease, curry was utterly tasteless. The saving grace was seafood rice. But hot and sour soup with shrimp and pork?? Pork in the soup looked like leftovers from last week.  

And my stomach complained the next day. Never had that before. Don't go in there, people.
author: S C.

description: Standard SF Cantonese food.  Dragon River has been here forever and is a local neighborhood favorite in the Inner Richmond.  Can't go wrong here for your $10 meal.
author: Laurence H.

description:
We came here last week after two years we visited this restaurant and i was a little bit of disappointed last time because the food didn't taste like the old ones. Last week was different, it looks like they changed the owner again, the food were pretty good. I love their beef with wine and pickle greens hakka dishes, and the calamari even though they need to tone down the msg a little bit, the shrimp ball was little bit on the bland side and dry. Definitely the beef with wine and pickle greens is my favorite, i could order 2 because it was so good. 

I'll go again to try out some other dishes and see if they are also as good as before.
author: sofie W.

description: The food here was actually surprisingly good. The mongolian beef was tender and spicy. The potstickers were good and the lady who took my order was very nice. Definitely one of the better chinese restaurants in the Richmond.
author: Darius A.

description:
Good introduction to Hakka Chinese food here; Hakka food is hard to find. Good food ; reasonable cost. Located not too far from Park Presidio and Geary.
Decor: eh.
author: Bert K.

description:
i've been coming here since i was little.  the food has always been very consistent and super good.  only thing that prevented me from giving 5 stars?  the service!!!

after the change of ownership, the service shot down into the ground.  the waiter (it's the same guy everyday) will blow his nose on a pretty frequent basis and without washing his hands, he will serve the food.  one time his thumb landed in my food and i just could not eat it anymore.  another con?  they stopped serving dessert.  the place has also gotten really dirty over the years.  sigh.  the old owner was really nice and clean.  now, he's gone away to i don't know land.

anyhoo, i normally order a good variety of food when i come here.  but, i always order the twice cooked pork patty with salted fish and snow pea sprouts with garlic.  coming here with a large group is great because you have the option of ordering lots of food.  the price is decent and the serving sizes are perfect.  i don't think i've ever had anything bad here.  this is definitely my favorite chinese restaurant in the bay area.  

it's just a shame that i can't come to eat here in peace.  i'm always wondering whether or not the waiter washed his hands with soap and water rather than wipe them on his clothes.
author: Jen W.

description:
Typical Chinese...fast, cheap with family sized portions. I came here for a quick meal with friends from church and we ordered one plate each and it was more than we could eat. 

We got the Gon Chow Ow Hor (Beef with Flat Rice Noodles), Gai Si Chi-in Mein (Chicken with Deep Fried Noodles) and the Yin Yang Chow Fan (Yin Yang Fried Rice). All three came out fast and were piping hot. I always loved the Chi-in Mein because it's crispy, yet flavorful with whatever's on top. The Ow Hor was okay and so was the Chow Fan. Oh, we were given a bowl of corn soup before that and it was okay too. 

Can't say much about Chinese food. Every place you go to is the same and the waiting staff gives you a monotone service unless you know them well or you order a butt load of food from them. Don't expect too much. At least it was clean and tidy.
author: Jeremy L.

description:
3 words say it all:

ROACH IN RICE
(they even had the audacity to charge for it on the bill)

Bugs in food aside, there are at least five places better than this within a 10 block stretch on Geary alone (Five Happiness, Lucky Fortune, Golden River, Old Shanghai, etc). 

Go here if you're looking for extra 'protein' in your rice. Otherwise, I'd recommend a pass.
author: Evan T.

description:
use to come here all the time because this is my dad's favorite chinese restaurant
owner use to be really cool cept he sold the place to his employee and now he works for him
owner use to hook it up all the time
havent been back here for years
but i do remember that the food being really tasty for chinese food
place is kind of dirty, typical chinese establishment
gets kind of crowded at time
i think the place fell off a little bit ever since new management took over
author: Andi I.

description:
A customer of mine always ate a lot here during his lunch hour.  I decided to check it out since it is next to Ariake's (another fav sushi spot of mine).

I like this place, because they cook up Hakka style Chinese food very nicely.

My favs are the (1) hakka beef ball soup, (2) wine-braised beef tripe with picked greens, and of course, (3) the salt-baked chicken.

Very nice flavors.

My goal is try most of their menu.  Wish me luck :)
author: Derek N.

description: Small family restaurant, I use to come here when my aunt would visit from Thailand and our families would have big dinners here. But it's been a long while. My parents and I were actually trying to go to the Sichuan place next door but it was so full, so we came here instead. We loved it. Great service, cute family and good food. Great portions, we had to bring  two dishes home because we were so full. Very flavorful and colorful dishes. We would go back again, my parents found another place they'll order from, and they aren't easy to please.
author: Kimberly S.

description: Authentic Chinese food done right. We love the non greasy, non overly sauced or salted taste that most people think Chinese food should be. The portions are reasonable and the price is unbeatable. We have always received excellent customer service and have enjoyed every meal there over the years.
author: Lara C.

description:
Under the new management, Dragon River has a new Chinese name, a new interior upgrade and new exterior look. The menu is similar and I was told that the staff working in the kitchen are the same.

Tried this old friend under new management in mid-October, the food were good and the ingredients were fresh. The services were intentive and warm. We met some friends there that night and they go there very frequent too but we never bumped into each other before. We tried the set dinner and the portions were big and we like their option to offer dishes with no MSG. The pork chop with sweet and sour sauce is a must try. The crabs are so tasty and fresh. Fried rice is also our favorite.

Glad that our old friend is still there, just with a new name.
author: Roserrele W.

description: The food is pretty good.  I live in the Sunset and I order pick up from this place because all the Chinese Restaurants in the Sunset suck and they're lazy!  I recently tried to order food and I was greatly disappointed.  The guy who answered the phone was a total jack off.  He didn't pay any attention to my order.  After repeating myself numerous times, he just said ok and hung up.  He didn't tell me the total or when the food would be ready (important details).  What the fuck?!  I called back and lit a fire under his ass.  He didn't apologize or anything, he was like, "whatever".  I guess business is good they can blow people off.  I will never order food from here again.  If they don't give a shit about their business why should I?  Fuck 'em :)
author: Ryan H.

description:
Craving Chinese.

Craving soup.

Oh, fuck it.  Despite this joint being empty and not a soul in sight, I acquiesced because the fellow did a quick scan on his iPhone and per Yelp (yes, you heard that right) the reviews for the other place was slightly mediocre.  Ok.  I swallowed my breath and we walked in.  Hmmm.  Cantonese/Hakka cuisine.  I was intrigued.

The take-out menu here was immense.  So much so, that even this Asian was totally lost and the fine print became smaller to escape detection.  I usually go with a noodle dish with a meat dish and then balance out the salty with a sweet dish.  

Despite my craving won ton soup, we decided to get the House Chow Fun with steamed bok choy and lots of stir fried beef, drizzled with gravy.  The meat dish was to satiate his inclination for anything ginger and instead of beef (I'm not too happy about the kind of beef utilized in many a Chinese restaurant.......the wrinkled slices seem to resemble the mixed hapa child of Arby's and the local Korean beef dish) so I slipped in my two cents and we had it upped to pork instead.  This dish was so gingery I almost passed out: hot peppery slices of fresh ginger, zinged with bits of sweet pineapple.  Pretty impressive and the fellow was delighted, even when I was throwing the extra slices of ginger onto his plate.  In addition, I've tried their standard chow mein here and it was chock full of vegetables and thick slices of char siu, just the way our Chinese neighbor use to throw together and bring over for NYE.  

In all, decent prices and everything for around $25 or so.  Then, they pulled the typical move on me.  Every time I hit a Chinese restaurant and the person I'm with is not Asian, they forget to throw in chopsticks.  FAIL!  I had to request chopsticks for the both of us, although I'm not really one to assume anything.

Another plus?  They deliver.  That's right!  Minimum order is $15 but they deliver, woohoo!  Great food, nice staff and looking forward to trying other items on their menu moving forward, perhaps their appetizers and chicken dishes.  Soup may be on the menu next, given this sudden cold front moving through again.  Brrrr!
author: Miika M.

description:
Met up with a friend who was coming from north of SF, so this was a decent midpoint.  We ordered duck, Chinese broccoli, spicy garlic chicken, and a side of rice.

Everything was well done, especially the duck, and had a decent level of spice and they let us stay a bit past closing time (though we felt bad and left shortly after we saw they were ready to go home).  I would go back again.
author: Bryan M.

description:
This place is just okay and nothing to really write about. It is a small restaurant on Geary Street but you can't miss it because it has a fairly large sign. 

When we arrived there was only one other table occupied but as the time went on, more people came in to eat. 

Service was friendly but slow. We asked for water 3 times until they finally brought us some. We had to continually ask for things like our last dish when everything had been out for a good 5 minutes. 

We ordered a chicken won ton soup, a fried shrimp dish and tofu dish. All mediocre and sub par as far as restaurant food goes. The won ton soup was hot so that was good. The fried shrimp dish was pretty tasty but not what we expected from the definition in the menu. The tofu dish was boring and super bland. in fact, we brought it home for dinner and my husband transformed it into something a lot better with better flavors. 

Overall an okay experience....service and food are okay....but probably wouldn't be back with all of the other places in the area.
author: Monica L.

description:
I had a sudden craving for Dragon River's chicken noodle soup yesterday, which is what prompted me to write this review.

My friends and I ventured here on a cold, drizzly Saturday afternoon.  I didn't really know what to order, but my ex-boyfriend was like, OMG you HAVE TO GET their CHICKEN NOODLE SOUP.  I'm thinking, chicken noodle soup at a Chinese restaurant??

Yes, yes and yes.  It was nothing like my favorite comfort food, but it was oh-so-delicious.  Egg noodles, a big bowl of chicken soup.. heavenly on a cold rainy day.

Their menu is huge and very conducive to the family-style eating that we Chinese people just love.  The service, because it was kind of empty, was great - they were very attentive and let us move tables to get away from the draft every time the door opened.

So, moral of the story, go when it's not crowded, like in the middle of the afternoon, and you'll be pleasantly surprised by the food and the service.
author: Tori S.

description:
I went to this place today for dinner. first of all let me tell u that the restaurant
is very cold and drafty. the food however is excellent and very reasonable, soup and two dishes total with drinks $30.00.
author: tracy y.

description:
$13 (per person) for dinner and left overs for lunch the next day earns this place an extra star.  Its nearly impossible to ever see me bring any food back because I typically finish it off in a sitting.

-Mushroom soup with crab meat. goooood.  I had about 4 bowls of that myself.  None of it made it home that night.

-Some type of fried prawn.  It didn't really stand out too much but it adds a little variety to the rest of the meal.

-I loved their veggie dish.  I totally can't remember what they are called, but its a very typical chinese veggie with oyster splashed on it.

-Fried rice was good stuff.  It isn't out of this world, but it compliments everything else.

-I liked the beef dish included in the meal.  The sauce was tasty but the meat could have been prepared a lil better.  It was a bit chewy.

If you're looking for a lot of food for a low price, come here for dinner combo C.  Your wallet will thank you, esp. in this current economy.
author: Tom Y.

description:
"I feel like Chinese too!" Cool, then our group of 4 won't spend an hour figuring out what we want. So we're driving along Geary and spot Dragon River. I say "Stop!" because my Chinese Zodiac sign is the dragon and I have a connection with reptiles. I'm thinking this is probably going to be a fairly authentic spot and after walking in, it is. 

Even though there are plenty of tables available with the lazy Susan, we get a small table without one. The beers were in a refrigerator right next to our table but the server still took about 10 mins to grab them. For suspense maybe? 

I ordered Mongolian Beef with a side of Shrimp Fried Rice. The beef was overly tender, which I assume is because of the OLD clientele, and the sauce was WEAK with barely any flavor. The Shrimp Fried Rice was oily white rice, steamed not fried, with 4 shrimps and a whole lot of wilted, brown lettuce. 

Other members of our party got equally unimpressive dishes, and had to wait around 20 mins for their fried rice. When we brought this up, the two servers began to argue loudly with eachother. This was not only uncomfortable for us, but drew the attention of everyone in the restaurant. 

I am quite puzzled as to why so many people give this a high rating. It's actually bad. Really bad, and not like "Oh, we didn't like the service" bad, but all around just bad. The flies everywhere should have been our first indicator, along with the not so fresh smell of mold that collects on the underside of the fishtanks.
author: Craig F.

description: I really want delivery right now, but every time I call the listed number a fax machine goes off.  I've had the food from here before and its pretty decent.  Get your phone connection issues sorted and we can move forward from there.
author: Michael M.

description:
I've accidentally stumbled into this place many times while waiting to eat next door at Ton Kiang(always a line).  I looked inside to see it packed with mostly Asian peps.  Always a good sign of approval when choosing Asian food. 

 I really like this place, however if you're looking for the foo foo dim sum that some people like, then this is not the place for you.  Try next door at Ton Kiang or down town at Yank Sing(which my Old Chinese parents will never let me bring them there again, ha).

Typical Chinese service-non attentive, rush in, rush out.  Not very helpful, but they are my peps!!!  I love it!!  it's super cheap too.  For about the same amount of food 
Ton Kiang- $55 bucks for 2 people
Dragon River- $29 bucks for 2 people
Yank Sing- $73 bucks for 2 people. 
Obviously you get what you pay for
Quality, service, environment, etc....
Cheap Crab too, it's okay, mostly fried and dry
author: Chase F.

description:
Can someone email me and tell me where the old chef went?

These guys only get 3 stars cuz the food used to be so good here a few years back, i think the cooked left.

ne ways other that the food now is ok and the portions are big.

The service is friendly and quick.

What to get 
tomato beef chow mein
tong choy
fried prawns
shezchaun vegetable and beef not on the menu
bitter melon and chicken with rice tell them to use less oil on this one though.

i would still come back once in a while for lunch because its quick.

p.s if neone knows where the old cooks are let me know.
THANKS
author: DOM d.

description:
this was lunch today after the bay to breakers run. I have been coming  for years and the food has always been consistence and very good. try the beef stew and the sweet and sour pork, I would stay away
from the chow fun. their westlake soup is also one of the best.
author: Howard J.

description:
I've been coming here since I was really young. The food has always been good and the green sauce has always been delicious. Ownership's changed and Bill the owner who used to give us a big bag full of fortune cookies sold it...but the food and green sauce haven't changed at all. The service is nice and friendly and the prices are good.

The green sauce...is a must.

I like their won ton and beef stew with ho fun. My parents like the moi choy kow yook (pickled cabbage with fatty pork), curry beef chow mein, chinese broccoli with beef, and ginger green onion chicken.

The name makes it sound like a typical corny chinese restaurant name, but trust me, it's not.
author: Tiff L.

description:
It's an okay place. Not bad, not extraordinary. The food is pretty cheap. The majority of the plates were in the range of $7.25 to around $8, and the plates I would say can feed 2-3 people.

I went with my bf, and we got: Potstickers, Egg Rolls, Chow Mein, Fried Rice, Salty Chicken, Beef and Oyster Sauce. All for around $40. It was a LOT more food than we expected. I think it was enough to feed 5 people.

I loved the Chow Mein, Egg Rolls, and the fried rice was tasty and felt fresh. I've had better beef w/ oyster sauce, and the Potstickers would've been fantastic if they were crunchy. It felt as if they were boiled and not fried too much.

I would recommend this place for people who want OKAY chinese food, and don't have too much money to spend.
author: Sophia G.

description:
Stopped in here for a filling home-style Chinese food meal, which this place delivered.

Food was fresh and plentiful. My favorites amongst the dishes we ordered (within the "C" family dinner for 2 or more) were the marinated flat steak pieces in a bbq sauce with sauteed onions and peas, and the crab and mushroom soup. At $13 a person, it was very reasonable.

My favorite part of the meal was when one of the cooks fished out a catfish from the back tank and dropped it in a bucket. We heard it flopping around, trying to jump to its death on the floor, but luckily it stayed relatively put. Pretty funny...although I did make my boyfriend face the fish tank during our meal. Now that's what I call fresh fish to order.

Wasn't particularly blown away by anything here, although I'd definitely come back, maybe for take out, or to try one of the crispy dishes outside of the set combo menu - they do have a vast selection.
author: Kelly R.

description:
Overall, very tasty.  Went there on Valentine's Day, hoping that not everyone else and their mother would be there, and they weren't, which was a good thing because we were hungry.  The West Lake Minced Beef Soup was an excellent suggestion -- maybe a little bland, but nothing that couldn't be fixed with a little soy sauce and pepper.  The salt and pepper ribs were good, but I can't do very much MSG so my boyfriend got to munch on the rest of those. The crispy chicken was excellent as well...the only thing I wasn't too impressed with was the steak cubes in black pepper and garlic sauce -- the steak was not cubed, they were more like filets, there was no hint of black pepper but plenty of green bell pepper, and it was rather fatty and frankly, just not all that great.  

We came back on Chinese New Year's Eve and the place was packed.  The service was still good though, fairly prompt, and the chicken with garlic and snow peas we got was 10x better than the steak.  

Yummers.
author: Sus... B.

description:
We never came here previously because the outside looked a bit skeptical. But because it was close to our church and there was no line, we decided to try it out. Boy were we surprised! The food is actually pretty decent considering the price. The staff was polite and accommodating. I LOVED the eggplant claypot but the fried rice was a bit weird - there was lots of lettuce in it  =\ 

We are happy to have found a new post church services lunch spot.
author: S H.

description:
Why is this place so empty every time I go? The food is great and the price is just right for the working middle class.  I usually come here with family for the $38 7-course special.  That includes the soup of the day, walnut shrimp, oysters/clams, pork belly, soy sauce chicken, sand dab, mustard greens, and fried pork strips.  Not only is this a value, the food is delicious.  Also, the chow fun is goooood - plus cheap.

I'm writing this as a food coma is setting in, so I'm going off of what my taste buds are telling me.  

The downside is that it can get kind of cold/chilly in the restaurant and it adds to an even lonelier feel to the place when a couple of tables are filled.  Besides that, this place is your "I hope this place never goes out of business" kind of restaurant because it's cheap and delectable.
author: Irene C.

description:
My aunt and uncle were visiting and they really wanted authentic Hakka cuisine.  So, of course, we went to Ton Kiang, but after looking at the menu, we realized they did not actually have a lot of dishes that were considered authentic (even the waitress noted that they took a bunch of items off the menu due to lack of popularity).  Yelp mobile helped me find Dragon River, just a few blocks down the way.

We were a little apprehensive walking in, but then saw a fairly full restaurant. with lots of Asian families.  We ordered a bunch of dishes and they were all really really good.  The service was not as speedy or attentive as Ton Kiang, but the food was fresh (get the salt and pepper shrimp and the oysters with black bean sauce) and the prices much more reasonable (bill for 5 people ended up under $60 without tip).  This is definitely more of a homestyle type of place, but that is how I like my Chinese food.

Don't be intimidated by the Chinese menu items on the wall -- the written menu includes pretty much everything on the wall (at lease that is what my aunt and uncle said) and is very extensive (and filled with regular Chinese food items).
author: Mitzi C.

description:
I was introduced to this place by a good friend of mine. He told me he had lunch there earlier that day and the food was so good he wanted to come back for dinner. I decided to see for myself, this is what we had:

Salt baked chicken w/ house sauce (their specialty)
Chicken/chines sausage Clay Pot
Fried Tofu
Sated Fish w/ mixed vegetables 
Steamed Rice
Tapioca Dessert
$40

In the end I would have to say I was impressed. The Sated Fish was my favorite by far, I would highly recommend trying this dish. Also the House sauce that they use with the Salt Baked chicken was phenomenal. However one thing caught me off guard, when we walked in originally, the staff just stared at us from the back kitchen. So i guess service could be an area of improvement.

just my .02
author: jason l.

description:
Way good!  The service is prompt and friendly, the restaurant is clean, the prices are reasonable, and the food is great!  What more could you ask for?

We had the house special chow mein (which made the waitress/owner? think we were Malaysian), the honey walnut prawns, and a squid dish.  (BF asked for "some kind of crispy, salty squid," and this is what we got, which was totally delicious, even if it wasn't what he expected.)  The prawns were a little heavy on the mayo.  The chow mein was perfect!  In fact, I'm craving it right now.  Maybe I should order it for delivery.
author: Phuong T.

description:
I used to live a bit closer to Dragon River and would "take out " often.  That was when Bill the waiter got to know my big old retriever Gus who would patiently wait in front while I paid for food.  Well, Gus has been dead for over ten years now, but whenever I drop in for a wonton fix, Bill always asks about my "big dog".  When I say "no more" (with the finger swipe across my neck), he looks slightly confused and gives me a big overflowing bag of fortune cookies for my kid like a consolation prize.

I still love their wonton soup.  It is the soup that makes it tasty.  (Does anyone else remember the movie Tampopo?) And the wontons are fresh and plump....I like plump and plump likes me!  I can honestly say that I have never had a bad meal here, even though I tend to order variations of the same thing (chow fun, chow mein, chow fun, chow mein, chow fun, fried rice, c.f., wonton, more chow fun).  Actually I have had other dishes there on occasion and nothing disappoints.  

I am a big ginger lover and  I love, love, love the ginger condiment (if you take out, make sure you get a small container in your bag).  It is great with chow fun or rice......
author: Valerie L.

description: Had lunch today. Ordered the special Lobster with noodles and salt baked chicken. Both were good. Had too much food for one person. Took leftovers home for another 2 meals. Will be back if I am in the vicinity.
author: Ris N.

description:
I have mixed feelings about Dragon River.

First thing's first, the Staff are AWESOME. They have always been super nice, friendly, helpful, and genuinely interested in providing customers with a good dining experience. They are SO great that sometimes it can be a little awkward when the place is empty... you wind up getting maybe more attention than you want.

I love all the sauces and the chow fun is great, but all of the food is really quite greasy (which is not what I feel like 99% of the time). Someone else mentioned it and, yes, the fortune cookies are notably better than any other restaurant's cookies. I may not always know what to order since I am white, but most of the time it is pretty good.
author: Amanda C.

description: we found this place just down the street from our hotel. My boyfriend and i frequent SF and are planning a move there next year. So during our frequents, we try to stay in different neighborhoods, away from touristy areas and try local places. This place was awesome. Great service, so nice, friendly and food was top notch. We had hot and sour soup starter, perfect! He had general's chicken and i had mongolian beef, both perfect. portions were a little big but that would be okay if we had a place to take them "home" to. Hard to do that in a hotel. We shall be back!
author: Lesley B.

description: My second cousin took me here.... We try the salty chicken .... It is very goooood .... If I visit SF again.... I'll definitely visit this restaurant again!
author: Steven W.

description:
Good place for Hakka food.  There are lots of choices and reasonable prices for dishes or set menus.  Must try the 2-3 sauces(green one) with your chicken or other entrees.  
Parking may be tough in the Richmond, but this place is worth a try.
author: Eric Y.

description:
Living in Inner Richmond I am amazed that I have only eaten at a handful of Chinese restaurants. Maybe it's the fact that there are so many we never know which one to go to. We finally decided to try Dragon River. We ordered the Steamed Bacon w/Dried Mustard Greens ($7.75) - wow that sucker musta been cooking for a while. The meat was incredibly soft and filled with so much flavor. Very yummy and for those who like the fat on pork this has a big thick chunk of it.

The Honey Glazed Walnut with Prawns ($9.50) was amazing. Nice sweet coating on the shrimp but not too sweet. I had to get the crispy noodles ($6.75) since I have been on the look out for some. It wasn't bad but I need to see if this is different from Hakka Chow Mein. I'm really looking for cake noodle and haven't a place that makes this.

And we also got an order of Crispy Fried Won Ton. Lotsa meat and very light wrapper making this one of the mos delicate fried won tons I've ever had.

Service was attentive and everyone very nice. Can't wait to go back and see what the Hakka Chow Mein is about. Free delivery for $15 or more!
author: Wendy B.

description:
Pretty good food and even though the place was totally packed, the service was good--the waiters were even pleasant considering their business. 

Seems like one of their specialties is a wine braise with pickled greens. We tried the wine braised meat stuffed tofu. Pretty tasty, but the rock cod fillet clay pot was better. The hot and sour soup was tasty, not the totally generic version, but pretty good.

The seafood combo with XO sauce was just ok....
author: Hank S.

description:
This place has the potential to be a good chinese restaurant.

We went here for dinner last night, around 8:30PM.  We were the only ones there the entire time, from entrance to exit.  Ive been trying to satisfy my craving for good chow mein here in the city, and after a huge failure at dragon well (which, btw, is HORRIBLE), we decided to try this place due to the 4/5 star rating (34 reviews).

We got Chicken Chow Mein, which was not cooked at all. The noodles had potential to be really yummy, but they didnt boil it enough, thus, the core was hard.  Everytime I bit into it, i felt like i shouldnt chew because it may get stuck in my teeth.  No-no.

We also got the salt & pepper sauted sea bass, which, when we got it, was deep fried, with jalapenos and onions. This is not sauted. We didnt really care, considering this kind of stuff goes on all the time in chinese restaurants, and gave the fish a try.  Not good. After the first bite, I was craving tartar sauce. Yea, that's how bad it was.

We got the pot stickers, which was hard, and tasted like it was just heated up. 

around 9, the staff started eating dinner themselves in the restaurant in a big circle, which is fine, because all other chinese places do that. But man, when we're asking for tuppaware, dont look at us like we're bothering your dinner. Geesh.

All in all, never again.
author: Chieko H.

description:
i came here for my sister's bday dinner.  she picked this place b/c of the pretty good reviews on Yelp.  the food didn't disappoint.  i had a good experience.  salt baked chicken, salt and pepper scallops were definitely the highlights.  although everything else we ordered was good too.

the service is fast and friendly, although only half of the restaurant was filled when we ate here.  

i'll definitely come back.
author: Tina L.

description:
Really?

Come on Yelpers. I look to you for guidance. I just moved out to the Richmond and wanted some Chinese for dinner. Yelp says 4 stars, so I was pumped.

I'd be lying if I said I remembered the name of the dish I got. Something chicken. But um, they left the flavor out. It was the most bland Chinese food I've ever eaten.

As far as MSG goes, I *wish* they'd have put some in, seeing as MSG is a "flavor enhancer". Man this food needed it.

The food looked great, and the vegetarian eggrolls were actually pretty decent, but the chicken, and the sauce, and even the vegetables... I don't know... It just didn't really do it for me.

"Meh. I've experienced better?" Uh, yea I have.
author: jared c.

description:
Used to be a huge fan of this place - if we went up to the city, this was a must go place for dinner - Not anymore since I felt  they over charged us on several occasions for the "special" menu.

Must try: layered fatty pork belly with preserved vegetables and deep fried shrimp balls.

Parking can be a bit of a challenge
author: Anton R.

description:
Okay food, very ordinary.  I suspect that's partially a result of our very ordinary menu -- Westlake Soup, Mongolian Beef and Rock Cod in Black Bean Sauce.  The cod was very good (easy four stars.)  The soup was rather bland and the beef was too sweet and not hot enough.  I think if we had ordered more Hakka-ish, then we would have been more satisfied.  I'm ready to raise the rating if it's better the next time I go back, but I gotta rate on what was served, not the potential.

The staff is very nice.  The woman-in-charge/owner(?) came over and chatted with us a little bit.  She made me feel a little bad about being Chinese and not being able to speak it, but that's just guilt on my part  more than anything else.
author: Eric W.

description:
It was all good, till we find a dead cockroach in our rice bowl.  
Beware of it when you go there.
author: Paul W.

description: I highly suggest not wasting your time or appetite coming to this restaurant. The service was terrible, it took at least 20 minutes for them to take our order, and not only that, I ordered fried rice with my meal and was served it after I finished my entire entree. The environment itself was more than uncomfortable, the servers ignored us and argued in front of us after sending the fried rice back. It was a terrible experience and does not deserve the 4 stars yelp has given them.
author: Veronica L.

description: I live in the inner Richmond, and there seems to be a disappearance of Cantonese restaurants.  Too many Chinese Japanese owned restaurants that use to be Chinese. Ever since the new owners took over Dragon River, I find the food some of the best Chinese food in the neighborhood with carefully prepared food that is not salty or greasy.  Huwang is a friendly, gracious owner who makes dining there enjoyable.  My sister and I agree that the level of cooking is consistent.  I love the beef stew won ton soup and the bitter melon beef.  Try it.  It's delicious.  Roland
author: Roland P.

description:
What a find - and in striking distance of the apartment.  The folks who run it are kindly and ready to suggest dishes.  This is my first foray into Hakka cuisine, and they've made me a regular.

I need to order some of the fresh fish, since they're swimming in the big tank in the back.  

The salt chicken was an incredible suggestion from one of the ladies who works there - I think she runs the joint.  I had never tasted this dish and I was surprised how good it was.  

My cousin from France just loved the food.  Chinese food in France is pretty bland compared to this.  

We ordered a beef dish the first time we set foot in Dragon River: wow.  It was packed with very well sauteed garlic - cooked to the point of tasting almost like nuts.  Very mild, unlike the raw garlic "assault" that so many others seem to prefer.  Made a devotee outta me!
author: Curtdude T.

description: Exceptional and incredible hakka chinese cuisine. I love their crispy chicken, salt and pepper prawns, and braised tofu with mushroom. It takes about 20min to prepare the crispy chicken but it's so worth it. Ask for the green and ginger garlic condiments. I used them to mix with rice. It tastes really good. The service here is impeccable. They are very friendly, affable, and treat you like a family. I got a box of free chinese fortune cookies and free desserts!
author: Michael K.

description: I grew up on Hakka food. My family and I use to go Ton Kiang before it became fancy spancy and snooty. Dragon river is much better. I love everything here: from the eggs w/bbq pork to the salt baked chicken to the steamed bacon , even the fortune cookies are above average.
author: Sophia C.

description: 5 stars just for the spicy prawns on their Specials menu. They are deep fried in a light batter then smothered with a hot, sweet and spicy sauce. MMMMM. Order this, eat it with rice and you're good to go.
author: Christine C.

description: Place was SOO dirty! bugs and flies all around... Food was okay, no need to ever go back.
author: Cathy N.

description: A great neighborhood place.  Chicken, "bacon," greens.  What homestyle cooking should be.
author: Jane M.

description: Standard Chinese, made memorable by the lady who took my order making a point to go into the kitchen and ask multiple times that my prawns and veggies be steamed, no oil. Thanks. Too bad the shrimp allotment in my dish was skimpy, otherwise this would be four stars.
author: Jason B.

description:
i've been coming to dragon river over 10+ years now and it's still one of the best places for chinese. since bill sold it a few years ago, some of the dishes have changed slightly, but overall still the same reliable signatures. 


my favs.

black bean chicken chow mein
salt baked chicken with ginger/garlic sauce on the side
salty fish chicken tofu clay pot
westlake soup
author: Thomas L.

description: Update!!!!  Owners changed and now food sucks!!!!!
author: Tee S.

description: My family loves to eat at these whole in the wall Chinese restaurants.  The food was decent but the quality was a little sub-par.  This is a very affordable place to dine and a quality place to bring the family...meaning my grandma.
author: Ginny M.

description:
perhaps we just didn't order the right dishes, but i thought the place was just mediocre. comments:

1. The ginger/garlic sauce that everyone raves about is just your typical hainan chicken sauce. I love the sauce, but you can get that at any HK/singaporean restaurant
2. the west lake minced beef, though decent tasting, had too much cliantro
3. garlic snow pea shoots (dou miao) was excellent
4. pepper spicy beef, i would not get again

damnit. should have gotten the chicken everyone talked about. despite the 3 stars, i'd come back and give it another chance.
author: Rene Y.

description:
I'm new to Hakka food and liked it.

A group of 7 guys came and ordered various dishes which we all shared.  The Mongolian beef was especially tasty, different, and interesting.

It is a medium size restaurant (probaby sits ~45) and there was at least one table that 7 of us sat at quite comfortably.

We were riding the bus, so parking was no problem.
author: T-Squared S.

description: Always filled with locals, not matter what time... always a good sign when there are so many Asian restaurants in the area. Great food - chow mein and walnut shrimp one of the best - and good prices, as well.
author: Samantha W.

description: Food is run of the mill chinese. ordered to go this week and when i had come in 15 min later to get my order they had forgot and hadent made it. They told me "it wasnt ready yet" and did not offer even an apology even tho i had to wait around for 10 mins for them to make it. Also when i got my order  i asked for soy sauce, the woman working there gave me one packet, when i asked for a few more packets she gave me a dirty look and proceeded to make me wait for 5 mins while she finished another transaction before she went to get me another. Rude customer service and mediocre food.
author: Simone C.

description: Good food.  After reading the reviews we decided on the crispy chicken, salt and pepper ribs, West Lake mince beef soup, and steak cubes in black pepper and garlic sauce.  The soup was a bit bland but really stimulated the appetite and we really enjoyed it.  My girlfriend is a bit sensitive to MSG and she thought there was some in the ribs, but it wasn't enough to set off a reaction and I got to eat most of the rib (yum).  Over all we enjoyed our experience and plan to return to sample more of the menu.  Portions were good and we had plenty to take home afterwards.
author: Theron L.

description: Since my family is Hakka, this is the place where my parents will go to for Hakka cuisine.   The food is suprising very authenic.  My favorite here is there crispy chicken and their West Lake mince beef soup.  My parents loved the pork intensine with pickle vegatables (typical Hakka dish) but no way in hell I will ever touch that, so if you are daring, give it try.  If you are  scare of the more exotic dishes, they have a lot of  the Chinese staples and their "normal"  meat dishes that have yet fail me yet.   Their tapioca in the end also rocks!
author: Chris C.

description:
the mongolian beef was awesome! tender beef , sauce, veggies and spiced spot on - so good! i could eat a whole 'nother plate right now. my partner had the prawns with the honey walnuts - it was pretty decent, the shrimp could have been a littler hotter/sweeter/crispier. we also got pot stickers, but they were just too big to be good - i don't think i've ever had pot stickers that big. the waitress was nice and the food came out quickly - we'll def. go back.

updated 8/13 the lemon chicken is soooo good! my partner's friends also loved the chicken fried rice and cashew chicken.
author: Toisha T.

description: Decent, but anybody rating this higher than 3 stars really needs to head up the street to Kirin.   We did one of the family deals for dinner - loved the bbq won ton and mushrooms, but the beef and pork fried rice following didn't do much for me.
author: John H.

description: This is one of those unassuming Chinese restaurants that people such as myself tend to overlook because it is dominated by the many other restaurants on Geary street.  Well my friends, don't make that mistake and come here for some great food at great prices.  You pretty much can't go wrong with anything you order here but my family's favorites are ginger chicken, oysters with black bean sauce, salt and pepper pork chops and their specialty which they are known for is their chicken with wine sauce.  That dish is a must, it's absolutely heavenly.  For the more adventurous people look at the wall to see what the family dinner specials are.  Yes it's in Chinese, but you can ask the waiter or waitress what the items are.  They are pretty nice over there.  There is a $38 special that is an absolute steal.
author: Ben M.

description: Gotta do the XO beef Hong Kong style!
author: Mark W.

description: I will give 5 stars for this one. Just bought a take out from them yesterday for the first time and was pleasantly surprised - food was good, portions are big and consisted of meat, not onions and bellpepers(as in other places around the area). I liked the food and will be ordering again. Yes its typical chinese restaurant but I am happy to support small family business especially in this economy. So far the best chinese joint around Park Presidio that I found. People, go eat there.
author: Sashie G.

description: This is my kinda joint. There's this one dish that we Indonesians call Babi Hong ( Its a pork dish), That's what I always tell the waiter. I don't know what its called in the menu. It is the BEST!!!  Also Kangkung with shrimp paste, walnut shrimp, fried chicken fish fillet with black bean sauce, etc etc...its all delicious. You can't go wrong. They'll also give you a box of fortune cookies that I snack on my drive back to LA
author: Danny R.

description: This is a great authentic hakka chinese restaurant.  Use to be a 5 star because of great taste/price/portions but have changed owners/cooks so dishes has also changed.  The portions are smaller but still a great bargain.  They got this great ginger sauce that tastes great with anything.  Its a hole in the wall pretty good none-the-less.
author: J J.

description:
I had never had Hakka food before I went to this restaurant.  I told this to the owner/waitress and she recommended the steamed meat-stuffed bean curd and tender greens.  I sort of liked them but found them very salty and not spicy enough.  The next time I had the beef tripe (cow's stomach) which I liked a lot.  Also the triple mushrooms--very good.  But both were too salty and not spicy enough (although they gave me some chili sauce to add).

So that was my introduction to Hakka food.  The restaurant ambiance is very barebones but the owners are friendly and try hard to please.  The price was  reasonable.  It really comes down to whether you like Hakka food or not.  Personally I'd put it well below Szechuan and Hunan on the Chinese pecking order but ahead of Cantonese.  It reminds me of Taiwanese food and so if you like that, try this place.
author: Murray S.

description: Decent food and friendly service at a great price.  Convenient location on Geary near Park Presidio and the Golden Gate Park.  The Hot and Sour soup tasted freshly made.  The Minced shrimp on eggplant and peppers with fried tofu was excellent.  Eggplant and Green peppers were wrapped with minced shrimp and lightly fried, accompanied by a unusual mild black bean sauce.  Hakka Noodles was OK.  Service was very friendly.
